title: Interview with Qark
historical_context: This interview provides insight into the early days of virus creation and the hacker culture surrounding it, particularly focusing on the VLAD virus group.
target_audience: Hackers, virus writers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article features an interview with Qark, a prominent virus writer from the VLAD group, discussing his experiences, coding practices, and thoughts on the virus scene.
summary:
In this engaging interview, Qark, a notable figure in the virus writing community, shares his journey into computing and the creation of computer viruses. He reflects on his early experiences with viruses, including his first encounter with the X-Fungus virus and his initial attempts at coding. Qark discusses the evolution of his work within the VLAD group, detailing the various viruses he has created, such as Winsurfer and Horsa, and the technical challenges he faced. His insights into the motivations behind virus creation and the dynamics of the virus scene provide a unique perspective on this subculture.

Qark also touches on the balance between his personal life and his passion for coding, revealing how his commitment to the virus scene impacted his daily life. He expresses a mix of nostalgia and critique regarding the virus community, highlighting both the camaraderie and competition among groups. The interview concludes with Qark's thoughts on the future of viruses, suggesting a shift towards more sophisticated resident infectors, and his appreciation for the antivirus software landscape. This candid conversation not only sheds light on Qark's personal experiences but also encapsulates the ethos of an era defined by experimentation and rebellion in the digital realm.
